landing.description: Interactive graph editor for Computer Science enthusiasts.
landing.featured_visualizers: Choose between various visualizers such as Dijkstra SPF and Automata (NFA, DFA).
landing.featured_forall: Specifically designed for educators and students.
landing.featured_editor: Feature rich interactive editor for all supported projects.
landing.featured_storage: Unlimited online storage for sign in members to save their projects.
landing.featured_organized: Keep your projects organized for free

404.return_action: Click on the island to return

step1.body: This tutorial will guide you through the various elements of the application.

step2.body: is an interactive editor that allow students and educators create custom graphs and run Dijkstra's Shortest Path First algorithm on them.

step3.body: This highlighted surface is your editor. You can combine nodes and edges to create graphs.

step4.body: The menu bar will be responsible for most of the interactions with the editor.

step5.third: functionalities will manage any misconfigurations of your graphs.

step6.first: In case the graph is too big or too small for your screen, you can change the editor size using the

step7.second: allows you to snap graph nodes on top of it for increasing visual appearance.

step8.body: The various editor modes provide ways to manage node and edges.

step9.second: mode you can reposition any node. When a node or edge is selected you can

step10.second: mode you can create new nodes.

step11.second: mode you can create new edges.

step13.body: When you are done creating the graph, those actions will run the Dijkstra's algorithm step by step.

step14.second: action button, starts the editor into play mode. You cannot edit your graph while being on this mode. To exit this mode, click the

step15.second: action button, sets the algorithm to its initial state.

step16.second: action button, sets the algorithm to its previous step.

step17.second: action button, sets the algorithm to its next step.

step18.second: action button, sets the algorithm to its final state.

step19.second: menu you can find options to save and load your graphs locally.

step20.body: By signing in you can save your projects to online storage.

step21.first: You can restart this tutorial any time by clicking the

step22.first: Congratulations, you have completed the tutorial!

appbar.discard_changes_body: All unsaved changes will be deleted if you confirm this action.

node_editor.title: Edit Node
node_editor.name_input_help_text: Allowed names are all values from a through Z.

edge_weight_editor.title: Edit Edge
edge_weight_editor.weight_input_help_text: Use any negative or positive integer.

edge_input_editor.title: Edit Input
edge_input_editor.edge_input_input_help_test: Single character values separated by comma (eg. a,b,c). Use @ for Îµ transitions.

create_modal.project_created_body: Close this window to start working on your project

errors.one_initial_state: Automata should have exactly one starting state
errors.one_final_state: Automata should have at least one ending state
errors.input_prohibit_symbols: Input string must contain only symbols from the alphabet

stepper.prohibit_optional_step_skip: You can't skip a step that isn't optional.
